pullRequest.body:
Add the Poisson probability distribution for non-negative rate `r`
- PMF
- Measure
- Basic API 
---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body: @sgouezel I agree that a positive parameter is easier. I wrote this to allow people to take limits where the rate goes to 0; a similar case was suggested to me for the Gamma/Exponential distribution. I’m happy to change this though if Remy agrees! I just went for generality of results here

I am not sure my comment was clear: I am not suggesting to take the rate in the type of strictly positive reals, I am suggesting to take the rate to be an arbitrary real number, because real numbers are just easier to manipulate than nonnegative real numbers (but for a nonpositive number the Poisson measure would just be defined to be the Dirac mass at 0).

> I am not sure my comment was clear: I am not suggesting to take the rate in the type of strictly positive reals, I am suggesting to take the rate to be an arbitrary real number, because real numbers are just easier to manipulate than nonnegative real numbers (but for a nonpositive number the Poisson measure would just be defined to be the Dirac mass at 0).

My bad, I mistakenly read ‘positive’ instead of ‘real’ for some reason. I agree that it would make things easier, although I’m not sure how well adding up independent Poisson distributions will go if negative rates are mapped to the Dirac measure, but we could require nonnegative real rates there I guess. (I’m planning to add some more basic API later). Also, the expressions for the characteristic functions would become more cumbersome for a real parameter, as we then need to pass to cases there.

Yes, all the relevant lemmas would require an assumption `0 ≤ r`. In fact I'm not sure anymore this is a good idea, probably the same rationale as for the gaussian applies. Let's see what @RemyDegenne thinks.

I am not sure that changing to a real rate instead of NNReal is a good idea. It would add a lot of nonnegativity assumptions, while now there are almost none (especially since the `if` in the measure definition is not needed).

I've incorporated the feedback and am lifting relevant feedback to #9561 as well (which defines the geometric distribution), so once this one merges, I think that one should be relatively easy! The only point there is that I'm not sure what the best way is to encode that the probability `p` should lie in `(0,1]`, so I'm open to suggestions there!

Thanks!
bors d+

:v: JADekker can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

Excellent, thank you @RemyDegenne! I'll tell bors to merge once the build is complete! 

 If you don't mind me asking, could you take a look at #9561, which defines the geometric distribution? I have incorporated all feedback from here there as well, but I'm not sure about how to require the probability to lie in `(0,1]`, do you think the way I do it now is correct?
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7478457615/job/20353464550)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7478457615/job/20353464841)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7478457615/job/20353464162)

@RemyDegenne, the PR uses a non-negative real as the rate to a Poisson distribution, just like you did for the variance of the Gaussian. For the Gaussian, one can argue it makes sense as all nonnegative variances are allowed, but here since one needs anyway a side condition that the rate is positive, I would probably just use a real number to make things simpler. What do you think?
For `r = 0`, isn't `(poissonPmf 0).toMeasure` already equal to the dirac at 0? If so, you can just remove the `if`.

I think you are right yes! For a continuous distribution, things are a bit more subtle, which is the case I had in mind as I was working on the Gamma distribution recently, but here it is fine indeed! I’ll change that after I know how we will deal with the non-negativity of the parameter

```suggestion
instance isProbabilityMeasurePoisson (r : ℝ≥0) :
```

```suggestion
/-- The Poisson pmf is measurable. -/
@[measurability]
lemma measurable_poissonPmfReal (r : ℝ≥0) : Measurable (poissonPmfReal r) := by measurability

@[measurability]
lemma stronglyMeasurable_poissonPmfReal (r : ℝ≥0) : StronglyMeasurable (poissonPmfReal r) :=
  (measurable_poissonPmfReal r).stronglyMeasurable
```
Can you close the section somewhere sensible, like before the definition of the measure, and close the namespace at the end of the file?

Can you please use the notation `x!` for the factorial of x? You might need to `open scoped Nat`.
Also, `x` is not a great name for a natural number. Use `n` everywhere?

```suggestion
  apply (hasSum_mul_left_iff (exp_ne_zero r)).mp
```

```suggestion
    IsProbabilityMeasure (poissonMeasure r) :=
  PMF.toMeasure.isProbabilityMeasure (poissonPmf r)
```

Is that instance actually necessary? `PMF.toMeasure.isProbabilityMeasure` is also an instance. Could you try to prove `IsProbabilityMeasure (poissonMeasure r)` by `inferInstance` (or the tactic `infer_instance`) and see if that works?
If it works, you can remove `isProbabilityMeasurePoisson`.

I just tried that, it doesn't synthesize the instance. However, when I'm using `rw [poissonMeasure]` followed by `infer_instance` it does do the trick, so perhaps there is something like a `@[...]` or something that would allow `inferInstance` to peak under the hood of `def poissonMeasure` so it can draw this conclusion on its own?
I just made a new commit, all other points have been incorporated!
Thanks for checking. I was unsure about whether the typeclass inference system could see through `poissonMeasure` or not. Since it cannot, let's keep the new instance.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - Feat : Define the Poisson distribution

nodes.body: @RemyDegenne, the PR uses a non-negative real as the rate to a Poisson distribution, just like you did for the variance of the Gaussian. For the Gaussian, one can argue it makes sense as all nonnegative variances are allowed, but here since one needs anyway a side condition that the rate is positive, I would probably just use a real number to make things simpler. What do you think?

@sgouezel I agree that a positive parameter is easier. I wrote this to allow people to take limits where the rate goes to 0; a similar case was suggested to me for the Gamma/Exponential distribution. I’m happy to change this though if Remy agrees! I just went for generality of results here

I am not sure my comment was clear: I am not suggesting to take the rate in the type of strictly positive reals, I am suggesting to take the rate to be an arbitrary real number, because real numbers are just easier to manipulate than nonnegative real numbers (but for a nonpositive number the Poisson measure would just be defined to be the Dirac mass at 0).

> I am not sure my comment was clear: I am not suggesting to take the rate in the type of strictly positive reals, I am suggesting to take the rate to be an arbitrary real number, because real numbers are just easier to manipulate than nonnegative real numbers (but for a nonpositive number the Poisson measure would just be defined to be the Dirac mass at 0).

My bad, I mistakenly read ‘positive’ instead of ‘real’ for some reason. I agree that it would make things easier, although I’m not sure how well adding up independent Poisson distributions will go if negative rates are mapped to the Dirac measure, but we could require nonnegative real rates there I guess. (I’m planning to add some more basic API later). Also, the expressions for the characteristic functions would become more cumbersome for a real parameter, as we then need to pass to cases there.

Yes, all the relevant lemmas would require an assumption `0 ≤ r`. In fact I'm not sure anymore this is a good idea, probably the same rationale as for the gaussian applies. Let's see what @RemyDegenne thinks.

I am not sure that changing to a real rate instead of NNReal is a good idea. It would add a lot of nonnegativity assumptions, while now there are almost none (especially since the `if` in the measure definition is not needed).

I've incorporated the feedback and am lifting relevant feedback to #9561 as well (which defines the geometric distribution), so once this one merges, I think that one should be relatively easy! The only point there is that I'm not sure what the best way is to encode that the probability `p` should lie in `(0,1]`, so I'm open to suggestions there!

Thanks!
bors d+

 If you don't mind me asking, could you take a look at #9561, which defines the geometric distribution? I have incorporated all feedback from here there as well, but I'm not sure about how to require the probability to lie in `(0,1]`, do you think the way I do it now is correct?
